title: slemish celebrations are back for st patrick s day
story: Slemish Mountain and the award-winning village of Broughshane will welcome thousands of visitors this St Patrick’s Day as the popular celebrationsto the area for the first time since .The traditional St Patrick’s Day climb of Slemish willon Thursday  March with a series of activities planned to make it a rewarding experience for all.Broughshane  District Community Association will provide the hub of the event in the village, with outdoor entertainment, including performances from the lively band, Ragaire, and the twenty-strong, Portglenone Comhaltas Group, traditional music and dance, street theatre, with crafts and face painting for the very young. It will be the first time since  that the traditional St Patrick’s Day celebrations will take place at Slemish following the outbreak of Covid-, with virtual events staged over the past two years.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, said: “St Patrick’s Day at Slemish and Broughshane is one of the most popular and best attended public events within the Mid and East Antrim Borough Council area with thousands attending it each year.“An exciting programme of history and culture has been put together for this event and I look forward to welcoming visitors to the area.”Chairman of Broughshane  District Community Association, Lexie Scott said: “We are absolutely delighted to be joining in the annual celebrations for Saint Patricks Day. We look forward giving the many visitors, who will come to climb Slemish, a very warm welcome to the village and the many retail opportunities it can offer.”The award-winning Naturally North Coast and Glens Artisan Market will attend for the first time, with over  stalls, offering visitors the unique market experience showcasing a wide range of artisan produce and high quality hand crafted goods. The one and a half kilometre walk at Slemish takes approximately one hour up and down and it is strongly advised that suitable clothing and strong footwear is worn. Sections of the short climb can be steep and slippery and might not be suitable for all. Don’t forget to pick up your climber’s certicate and medal back down in the village, though supplies are limited. There will be no parking at Slemish, Carnstroan Road or Carnstroan Lane, so a free park and ride service will operate from the former Michelin plant, Broughshane, just off the M.The shuttle bus to Slemish Mountain will run continually from am – :pm stopping in Broughshane village, so nobody will miss out on the free entertainment and shopping offers.This event has been supported by The Executive Office through Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s Good Relations Programme.For further information and download a guide for the day visit www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk stpatricksday

title: have your say on council s performance improvement plan 2022 2023
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has launched a consultation on its Performance Improvement Planfor the   period – its annual plan to support continuous improvement in the delivery of council services.During the consultation period, which extends to  May , residents, businesses and community groups across the Borough are invited to review the draft plan and have their say on Council’s proposed improvement objectives.Covering six key areas, the proposed improvement objectives for   are: Growing the economy and creating jobs. Supporting the communities within the historic conservation area of Carrickfergus, contributing to the sustainability of the local economy. Supporting MEA’s citizens’ health and wellbeing by providing quality, inclusive play and recreation facilities, and promoting safe and responsible outdoor recreation. Improving infrastructure to encourage electric vehicle uptake in the Borough to reduce emissions and protect the environment for future generations. Creating an Autism Friendly Mid and East Antrim Borough Council. Improving customer engagement and service delivery by enhancing Council’s use of information technology.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, is urging residents, businesses and community groups to engage in the consultation and ensure their views are heard.“As a Council, our duty is matched by our strong desire to drive performance and continuous improvement in the service we provide to the people of Mid and East Antrim,” he said. “To do so, we rely very much on their feedback and, as such, welcome all comments and suggestions received through this consultation process.“Underpinned by our Performance Management Framework, our proposed improvement objectives for the   period align closely to Council’s key priorities within our Community and Corporate Plans.“Our improvements focus on the issues that are important to the people of Mid and East Antrim, helping to improve the quality of le for all. For the upcoming year, we will also continue to focus on recovery and adapting to the ‘new normal’, taking proactive measures to minimise any lasting negative implications from the Covid- pandemic.”For more information about the Performance Improvement Plan and to complete the consultation questionnaire online, visit: www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk performance-consultationA printable copy of the consultation publication can be downloaded from the Council’s website and can be requested in an alternative format, such as large print or another language, by emailing communications@midandeastantrim.gov.ukHard copy consultation questionnaires should be ed to: Corporate Performance Team, Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, - Bridge Street, Ballymena, BT EJ.The consultation survey closes at noon on  May .The final plan will be taken to Full Council for approval before being published by  June , as is the statutory requirement.

story: It is understood that the man brought to head Mid and East Antrim Council has left his post after just over a fortnight.It was said that Mark Parkinson was on sick leave last week but it emerged on Tuesday afternoon that he has apparently left his job for good. title: behavioural change key to going green expert
story: Dr John BarryPeople have been urged to move away from a meat-based diet FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr John BarryAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWith heightened awareness around climate change and our environment, more and more people are looking for ways to “go green”.However, with the best intentions in the world, there are many perceived eco-friendly actions we are taking that turn out to be at best ineffective, and at worst counterproductive.Dr John Barry, Professor of Green Political Economy at Queen’s University, says there is a “general phenomena” of people undertaking green practices, but in another part of their le they are doing the opposite, counteracting all the “green good” they have done.“For example, people might recycle more or become more plant-based in their diet, but all the ecological advances of that will be cancelled outyou’re flying around the world,” he said.“It seems like common sense, but it is a recognised social behaviour.“There are also questions to asked around electric cars.“People think electric cars are the answer, but actually,you pop the hood on the electric car supply chain, you’ll find a lot of murky human rights abuses, and the extraction and exploitation of the environment in places where we have to mine things like zinc and magnesium, metals we need to make the batteries for electric cars.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Really, the solution is, as we’ve seen from the pandemic, work from homeyou can, or use active travel — walking or cycling. Then you can use public transport.“I do have a concern around the promotion of electric vehicles in that it is sending out the wrong signal. We should be urging people not to travelthey don’t have to, walk or cycle when they can, then use public transport, and finally go down the electric car route.”Many companies and products promote themselves as green or eco-friendly, but when you read the small print, they really aren’t, says Dr Barry.He also says there are problems with a plant-based diet.Moving away from meat and dairy can help the environment, but there is a danger of becoming reliant on processed vegan-friendly foods and ‘fake meat’ products.“Not only could they be harmful, but ecologically, the production of these processed products is not environmentally-friendly,” he added.“By going plant-based in our diets, we need to go for fresh forms of protein and carbohydrates, not processed food.“Unlike eating raw vegetables, processed vegan foods or fake meats use more energy in their production, like oil and gas.“It’s much more ecologically-friendly from an energy and climate point of view to avoid processed food.“We need to be focusing on ‘farm to fork’ in the real sense of the term, as every part of the journey of processed food from production to your table uses up carbon energy — processing in the factory, driving to supermarket, refrigeration, cooking.“The are other forms of dietary choice you can make that use less carbon energy in the chain from production to consumption.”Related title: how green is your candidate why its so vital to quiz politicians when they ask for your vote
story: Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGreen Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured.March   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPoliticians are increasing recognising that immediate and decisive action on the climate crisis will not only influence votes — it will win votes.Indeed, for many Northern Irish voters, climate action will be one of the defining issues in the upcoming MLA elections in May.With these elections fast approaching, many candidates have already started leafleting and door-knocking. However, when a candidate knocks at your door, what questions should you ask them  More importantly, how do you know whether they are genuinely serious about what they propose To gain a deeper sense of the candidate’s knowledge and understanding of climate breakdown, begin the conversation in the context of the broader political landscape.There are currently two climate bills passing through the Northern Irish Assembly. These are subject to ongoing debates, reviews and amendments. Both bills have a target of net zero emissions. Yet while the Private Members’ Billaims for Northern Ireland to be net zero by , the Executive Billaims for .Read MoreClimate: ‘Supporting that Bill would have led to the loss of , jobs in the farming sector’ – Agriculture Minister Edwin PootsYou could therefore start by asking the following question: which bill do they support Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Given how both bills aim for Northern Ireland to be net zero, despite ying target dates, a good follow-up question would be to ask how their party hopes to achieve this. How will they get us there  What is their political strategy  What concrete steps will they take to help Northern Ireland reach net zero Northern Ireland is not only the last nation in western Europe to implement climate legislation, but we also rank th worst in the world for bioersity loss. Nature recovery is therefore integral to an ambitious climate strategy.It is therefore crucial to ask the candidate about how they plan to halt and reverse nature and bioersity loss. How will they promote regenerative agricultural practices  How will they create more spaces for nature  How will they prevent the decline — and potential extinction — of our valuable species and wildle There are also three sectors in Northern Ireland which could be uniquely affected by the climate crisis: agriculture, energy and transport. These three sectors are vastly dferent. However, what unies questions regarding the future of these sectors is the principle of ‘just transition’.‘Just transition’ is the idea that we should not moveto a low-carbon, environmentally-friendly economyit means sacricing justice or ‘fairness’. A just transition recognises that, whether it be people on low incomes or workers in the fossil fuel industry, no one should be left behind in the creation of a ‘greener’ society.To take energy as an example, fossil fuels like oil and gas remain the primary source of heat and power in Northern Ireland. We already know that fossil fuels are harmful to the environment, and they will not help us to reach climate targets. Beyond asking candidate about renewable energy systems, we must therefore go one step further.We need to ask candidates about how they will compensate for workers in polluting industries, who may find themselves without a job in a more sustainable world. What incentive schemes will they promote  How will they re-train or upskill iniduals  How will government invest in this The same is true for agricultural and transport sectors. Will there be grants or public goods for farmers who dedicate areas of land to rewilding or regenerative practices  Will there be further investment in public transport infrastructure, particularly in rural communities  How will government incentivise citizens to support ‘greener’ lestyle choices that are typically more expensive, like buying an electric car or fitting solar  at home Lastly, ask the candidate seeking your vote about what is important to you.Whether it be plastic pollution or food waste, this is an invaluable opportunity for you to ask the candidate about a specic topic that you care deeply about. This could be an ongoing problem in your local area, or a global issue which causes you concern.Raising more personal questions with candidates may subsequently elicit a more direct response from them.Elections are a rare opportunity for citizens to shape environmental policy, and focus political attention on the most defining issue of our generation: the climate crisis.Climate change will be related to every social issue on each political party’s manesto – from gender equality to healthcare.Voting for candidates who support ambitious environmental policy solutions is therefore arguably the most important action that citizens can take.Remember this when candidates come calling.Related topicsEdwin PootsClare BaileyClimate ChangeClimate BillMore On Edwin PootsFriends of the Earth: Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:War in UkraineEnvironment In FocusHow Much Is Your House WorthSix NationsWeekendCoronavirusNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Kerbside boxes for every home to sort recycling ‘could save £m a year’ – and clean up the current dirty systemSystem used by many councils dirty, inefficient, and much more expensive than it needs to beSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIn the thundering heart of the facility where half of Northern Ireland’s waste is sorted for recycling, the scale of the operation is arresting.There are immediate observations — the banging, rattling, pounding intensity from vast industrial sorting machines, and the dirt which clings to surfaces. But more compelling is the awareness of how, just a few years ago, all of this valuable material was just dumped into holes in the ground.It’s a filthy business, but far less filthy than the alternative of landfilling the contents of our bins.Anyone who has lived near a municipal dump knows the stench, flies and rats which follow. The toxic nature of much waste means the sites are contaminated for generations, threatening groundwater and wildle.And yet,we all dump our waste into black bins, these sites must go somewhere. It is hypocritical for someone who refuses to recycle to object to a landfill site simply because it is close to their home, rather than close to someone ’s.As recently as , every year we sent , tonnes of municipal waste to landfill by last year that had fallen by %, even though the population increased in that period.Not all the reduction is because of recycling. Just over a decade ago no household waste was incinerated, but now , tonnes are sent abroad each year to be burned to make electricity.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up But recycling is the key explanation for the transformation. Driven both by legislative compulsion and growing public awareness of how we are polluting our world and wasting its resources, many people now put more into their recycling bin than into the black bin.Compostable and food waste is now collected separately and used for everything from garden compost to creating gas which can power lorries or make electricity.But what happens when the recyclable material leaves our homes  It is particularly hard to understand how the recyclable items put into blue bins or other comingled recycling bins — where all manner of materials are mixed — can be accurately sorted for processing.In an industrial estate in Mallusk, Bryson Recycling is where that process unfolds for much of the east of Northern Ireland. Bin lorries from five council areas — Belfast Antrim and Newtownabbey Ards and North Down Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid and East Antrim — arrive and leave in a constant stream.Mechanical rams push out each bin lorry’s contents into a hangar. A huge quarry shovel loads it onto a conveyor belt. Plastic bottles explode like fireworks as the vehicle’s heavy wheels drive over the material.The belt carries the waste into the deafening materials recycling facility . The process which follows is surprisingly labour-intensive, as well as using technology to separate the waste.First, a group of workers stand on a raised  and manually lt obvious contaminants from the conveyor belt.Secondly, the belt moves through screens designed to remove paper, which goes to a separate line.The third process involves a magnet that attracts steel cans, such as baked beans tins.That process is then reversed at the fourth stage as the remaining material is subjected to an eddy current that repels aluminium into a chute.The line splits into four conveyors which run through a sorting cabin — the fth stage — where a team of workers pick out materials by hand, aided by a prototype robot that recognises materials and lts then.The sixth stage sees plastics removed using optical sensors which recognise material based on how it reacts to light. A final process involves a worker again manually picking out recyclable items which have been missed.By this stage, more than % of the initial material has been removed. But it’s not perfect. I saw plastic bottles and paper dropping off the end after the final check.The conveyors move quickly and not even all the obviously recyclable material can be caught there is no time to explore items which look unclear. Small items such as bottle tops are particularly unlikely to be correctly identied, falling off the end of the line to be taken for incineration.There are two forms of contamination: material which is wrongly bundled together through the MRF-sorting process [such as plastic in bales of paper], and material which cannot be recycled at all at that facility and so is taken for burning.The contamination at the start of the process stems from a mixture of ignorance of ambiguous rules for what can be recycled in dferent council areas, and deliberate flouting of rules.Claire McCallum has been in the recycling business for two decades at Bryson. “We’ve probably seen nearly everything coming through the doors here,” she tells the Belfast .“We have an ongoing issue with nappies coming through, but also dead animals all sorts of things. We’ve had quite a lot of dead lambs.”Food waste in containers rots, both making the process of hand-sorting more unpleasant and contaminating the final material.What can the public do to help  “I think the best thing people can do is, rather than look at a certain type of material and think ‘oh, that can be recycled’, always check your local council website,” she says.“And the other thing is to ensure things are clean give them a quick rinse before recycling.”But the blue bin comingled recycling is only part of what happens at this facility. Bryson’s own-design vehicles move to another part of the site where no sorting is necessary because the materials have already been sorted manually as they were lted.It is this system Ms McCallum believes is the future.It produces far higher quality materials, almost % pure, rather than some plastic or metal inevitably ending up in a bale of paper. And it uses far less energy, unlike the vast electrical and mechanical demand of the MRF plant.There isn’t just an environmental benefit to the kerbside sorting. Counterintuitively, Bryson says it is also cheaper for ratepayers.“We have been looking at cost analysis and we have worked out thatevery household in Northern Ireland had wheelie boxes, it would save councils about £ million a year,” Ms McCallum says.The costs of sorting the material properly by hand are higher, but the processing costs signicantly less and produces materials which can be sold for a much higher price.So why were councils ever using blue bins  She suspects councils instinctively did so because they had been used to bins and bin lorries, and when told to recycle, they used what was familiar.When asked about this, a spokesman for Nilga, which represents councils here, said the issue was complex, but that the public should try to consume as little materials as possible and recycle the maximum quantity of what they do use.Bryson would like to see a single, consistent approach to recycling across Northern Ireland.Another benefit of improving the quality of recycled materials is that it makes it easier to sell to local firms and improves the quality of their products.Just % of MRF-sorted material stays on the island of Ireland for processing for kerbside-sorted material that figure is %.The high quality, low-contamination materials are not possible through an MRF facility, Ms McCallum says: “You can’t achieve that through recycling through a blue bin system.”Bryson’s plastic, paper and glass is recycled locally, supporting about  jobs and generating around £m a year.The paper is turned into moulded packaging like egg cartons and cup carriers by Huhtamäki in Dollingstown. Glass is melted in a Encirc’s furnace in Derrylin before being turned into bottles for Bailey’s, Bushmills, Fever-Tree, Bottlegreen and other leading drinks brands. Plastic is taken to Cherry Pipes in Dungannon where it is made into civil engineering and agricultural pipes.In one key area, Northern Ireland is now behind the Republic.Last year it became mandatory for recycling companies south of the border to accept ‘soft plastics’ such as the film lids to be recycled.Here that form of plastic makes up much of what still goes into landfill. It is not likely to be collected for recycling locally until .Dealing with waste is complex, but it can be over-complicated by government. For years, as the government prodded people to recycle and cut black bin collections, there was public grumbling.But public opinion has shted rapidly polling now finds public support for recycling.In the post-war decades it was a symbol of society’s growing wealth that a consumer could buy something new, use it for a while and then dump it in landfill because a newer model was available or a minor fault had developed. But that materialistic hedonism has become increasingly uncool.Now people want to recycle more, and do so more easily, but it is government that has not moved to satisfy this desire — either by not collecting basic items such as soft plastic or glass for recycling, or by using a system that will inevitably fail to recover a high percentage of what could be salvaged, and will inevitably contaminate even what is recycled.Stormont and our councils have the power to change this — but may only do sothey believe votes are at stake.Related topicsClimate ChangeMore On Climate title: time to fix the climate at any cost
story: Storm Eunice FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStorm EuniceMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailClimate scientists are unambiguous about the need for rapid reductions in carbon emissions to meet the aim of limiting average levels of global warming to . degrees Celsius.While the climate challenge has been recognised for years, a lack of action up to now ramps up the urgency to act. It is now two years since the Northern Ireland Assembly declared a climate emergency. Similarly, Belfast City Council declared a climate emergency in October .Across Northern Ireland, the average annual land temperature in the decade - was .°C warmer than the period from the mid-s to mid-s. The st century has so far been warmer overall than any of the previous three centuries. Winter  was the third warmest winter for Northern Ireland since .The changes in climate that we are already experiencing are projected to continue and intensy. In the second half of the century, the amount of change that occurs will depend strongly on how successful we are in reducing greenhouse gas emissions globally.Annual temperatures in Northern Ireland are projected to rise by approximately .°C by the s from a - baseline average. Risks associated with rising temperatures, such as more extreme heatwave events causing impacts on people’s health, are likely to become more prevalent as a result of these projections, with their magnitude depending on the degree of change that is experienced.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the time of writing, Northern Ireland remains without a climate bill, although the expectation is that this will soon be resolved. The Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs , led by Environment Minister Edwin Poots, and Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey have bills that have reached the consideration stage in the Assembly.Whichever bill emerges, it is clear that signicant change to our socio-economic model needs to occur to reach any of the proposed targets. In , Northern Ireland’s greenhouse gas emissions were estimated to be . million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. Northern Ireland accounted for % of UK greenhouse gas emissions in , compared to approximately % of the UK population. Agriculture , transportand residential buildingswere the largest sectors in terms of emissions. Mindful of the need to address this and maintain a viable economy, Daera has produced a draft green growth strategy which is about creating more green jobs and protecting or re-purposing existing jobs where possible.An important part of the draft green growth strategy is the new energy strategy from the Department for the Economy. It notes an ambition to deliver energy savings of % from buildings and industry by  and meet at least % of electricity consumption from a erse mix of renewable sources by .While the legislation may be edging forward and strategies are emerging, the current Northern Ireland report within the latest UK Climate Change Risk Assessment makes for sobering reading. The Government is required by the Climate Change Act  to conduct such an assessment every five years to inform the UK National Adaptation Plans for England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. The assessment covers  specic risks and opportunities in detail across themes such as infrastructure, health, the natural environment, international dimensions and business and industry.Taking the business and industry theme, issues such as increased flooding of business sites, increased levels of coastal flooding, access to finance, worker productivity and disruption to supply chains could all be at risk from climate change.For example, the annual bill for damage for non-residential properties in Northern Ireland is expected to increase by % by  due to flooding events. The expected annual damages for UK business properties from coastal flooding is expected to increase by % by .The Climate Change Risk Assessment also suggests that there is a risk that access to finance, investment, insurance, and capital for businesses are negatively impacted by climate change through decline in availability and affordability of insurance, a reduction in the value of assets and investment and increased credit risks and cost of capital.Across Northern Ireland, this is currently a medium risk, but it has the potential to rise to high magnitude in future.With these potential risks fast approaching, finding a path to net-zero is crucial. The net-zero carbon roadmap produced for Belfast is enlightening in this regard. Currently, % of Belfast’s emissions come from the domestic housing sector, with transport responsible for % of emissions, public and commercial buildings for % and industry %.Belfast’s roadmap includes an assessment of the potential contribution of approximately  energy-saving or low-carbon measures.I don’t think anyone knows where the money is coming from to pay for these initiatives, but it may be the case that a slowness to act has brought us to the point where we can’t quibble on the cost.Andrew Webb is chief economist at Grant ThorntonMost ReadFloundering council’s £,-a-day boss title: as petrol prices soar heres how to make a tankful go even further
story: Consumer Council says that now could well be the ideal time to make the switch to an electric vehicleExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseWeigh your options: Don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journey FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueWeigh your options: Don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journeyAmy CochraneTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailWith fuel prices at an all-time high, drivers are worried about keeping up with the soaring cost of petrol and diesel.Combined with huge rises in domestic energy and home heating oil prices, the added pressure of keeping on top of travel costs can only heighten stress levels when trying to keep within household budgets.However, there are a few small changes that many can make to ensure journeys are as economically efficient as possible.Now might even be the time for motorists to consider the possibility of going electric — which can not only help the environment in the long term, but can help motorists cut the costs on travel.The war in Ukraine has had a massive impact on crude oil prices, and these are set to soar further as the crisis continues.Average fuel prices hit a record high last week in the wake of the Russian invasion on February , with even the cheapest petrol up p per litre in just seven days — and motorists could be paying a whopping £ a litre by next month.Increases of more than p per litre have been spotted in filling stations right across Northern Ireland in recent days.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up One year ago, the most expensive place for diesel here was charging .p per litre, while the dearest petrol was .p. Just yesterday, prices reached well above p for diesel and over p for petrol.Latest research from the Consumer Council shows that the Northern Ireland average unleaded petrol price is .p per litre, or £. for a -litre fill at the petrol station. Northern Ireland’s average diesel price is .p per litre or £. for a -litre fill.Petrol and diesel prices have increased by .% and .% in the last  months, respectively.Consumer Council Head of Transport Richard Williams has said that this increase is “driven by factors outside the control of consumers” and as with domestic energy costs too, this contributes to “a worrying time” for consumers.“It is likely that these price increases will encourage drivers to rethink how they make their journeys,” he said.“In the short term there are small things you can do to make the fuel you buy go further such a maintaining your vehicle properly and properly inflating the tyres. You can also use our free fuel checker tool for a weekly guide to the best price within your area. It is available on our website,” he added. In the longer term, Mr Williams has suggested that this ongoing economic crisis may force motorists to consider whether it is time stop using petrol or diesel altogether and purchase an electric vehicle instead.“This is something all car drivers are going to have to do eventually as the UK government has already announced a ban on the sale of all petrol and diesel vehicles by ,” he said.“Currently only .% of vehicles in Northern Ireland are electric but this is increasing, with a % increase on electric vehicle registrations from  to .“Many consumers will have questions around the cost of purchasing and running an electric vehicle, where and how they will charge it and even whether the battery range is sufficient for their driving needs,” he added.“The Consumer Council continues to work with government, elected representatives, consumer bodies and industry to safeguard the people of Northern Ireland and ensure they have the information and support required in order to make the move away from petrol or diesel.”While fuel consumption has a lot to do with the car you buy, whatever you drive there are things you can do to save fuel, save money and cut pollutiongoing electric is not an option right now. top tips on saving fuel. Keep your tyres inflated. Under-inflated tyres will make your car use more fuel so always check the pressure regularly.. Reduce the drag. This could be by removing roof racks or boxes which all add to your fuel consumption. Pack carefully to reduce drag.. Declutter your car. Less weight means less fuel soyou don’t need it right away, take it out.. Don’t fill your car up with fuel. Fuel is heavy so don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journey.. Brake and accelerate less — both of these burn fuel. Try to drive smoothly, accelerate gently and read the road ahead to avoid unnecessary braking. Decelerate smoothly as well by releasing the accelerator in time, leaving the car in gear.. Avoid stopping and starting where possible. Roll up slowly for traffic lights or coming to a stop at a queue where you might not have to stop completely.. Get your car serviced regularly. For best efficiency to ensure your car is running as smoothly as possible.. Use the right specication of engine oilto improve efficiency.. Don’t hang around — idling wastes fuel and your engine warms up more quickly when you’re moving so don’t start the engine until you’re ready to go.. Plan your journey — getting lost wastes fuel. Check traffic news before you go too as well as sticking to the sat nav.. Combine short trips — cold starts use more fuel so it pays to combine tripsyou can.. Walk or cycle —you’re only going a couple of miles or so, do you really need to use the car . Use your air conditioning wisely — at low speeds, it increases fuel consumption but at higher speeds the effect is less noticeable. Try opening the windows around town and save the air-con for the motorway. Running it at least once a week helps keep it in good condition.. Cut down on the electrics — turn off your rear window heater, demister fan and headlights when you don’t need them. Stick to the limit — going faster uses more fuel. Drive at mph and you’ll use up to % more than at mph and up to % more than at mph. title: everything you need to know about the one off 200
story: Around , people in Northern Ireland are automatically eligible for a one-off payment of £, which will start being paid to iniduals from next Thursdayonwards.Who can receive the payment The one-off payment of £ will provide support for people struggling to meet rising energy costs due to the global fuel crisis.Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey said that from March  onwards, those in receipt of specied benefits will start automatically receiving the sum of £ directly into their bank accounts.Read MoreOne-off £ energy support payment to be rolled out from Friday, Deirdre Hargey confirmsEnergy prices will continue to rise for next  months at least, says Utility RegulatorThere is no need for a special application to be made. It will be made automatically to around , eligible people in receipt of specied benefits. The payment will be made through existing payment channels, without the need for an application.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Iniduals will be eligible for this payment , during the week of December  to December , , they were in receipt of one or more of the following benefits:• Pension Credit• Universal Credit• Income-related Employment and Support Allowance• Income-based Jobseekers Allowance or• Income Support.If you received any of these benefits during this time last December, you should automatically see £ arrive in your bank account from next Thursday onwards.Iniduals living in care homes from December  to December ,  inclusive are not eligible for this payment.Those in receipt of payment of contribution based Employment Support Allowance only or contribution based Jobseekers Allowance only are also not eligible.Read MoreMinister Deirdre Hargey confirms £ energy support payments to begin from March Ms Hargey has encouraged people to further contact her department’s Make the Call service, which is in place to connect people with the benefits, supports and services to which they are entitled.To #Make the Call# you can phone   , text ADVICE to , visit nidirect.gov.uk makethecall or email makethecall@dfcni.gov.uk.You may also be eligible for Discretionary Support or the Universal Credit contingency fund.What other financial help is available The Department for Communities said it has also provided a £m contribution to an Emergency Fuel Payment Scheme, a crisis fund operated by Bryson Charitable Group for households in immediate need and which may be at risk of disconnection, or who have been disconnected from their energy supply.The scheme launched on January  and as of February , almost , applications have been received, of which almost , were eligible. The department added that almost all eligible applicants received support within  hours.The scheme provides eligible households with one-off support of up to £ worth of electricity, gas, or oil.Over , people will receive a £ payment from  March to help heat their homes. I know that workers and families are struggling with the cost-of-living crisis and huge hikes to energy prices and I am committed to doing all I can to support them.— Deirdre HargeyMarch , Applications can be made up until the end of this month  and must be made via an online form, which will be available on the Bryson Charitable Group website from am and pm Monday-Thursday and am on Friday.You can check your eligibility for this payment scheme here. Criteria includes having received an electricity gas bill within the last five days, which you cannot afford to pay, and or having a total gross annual household income of less than £, .The Utility Regulator has also advised members of the public that are struggling with the rising energy costs, to try seeking the help of charities title: freedom here i come disability campaigners hail changes to northern ireland building regulations over inclusive toilet facilities
story: Finance Minister Conor Murphy with disability campaigners Christine McClements and Michaela Hollywood at the Changing Places facility at Stormont Estate. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFinance Minister Conor Murphy with disability campaigners Christine McClements and Michaela Hollywood at the Changing Places facility at Stormont Estate.Christopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA Northern Ireland disability campaigner has welcomed changes to building regulations which will provide additional toilet facilities for those with learning and physical conditions.Rights champion Michaela Hollywood, who lives with spinal muscular atrophy, has long campaigned over the issue of inclusive Changing Places toilets and hailed the changes announced as a landmark day, tweeting: “Freedom, here I come”.The announcement was made by Finance Minister Conor Murphy, who said the new statutory guidance would apply to certain buildings commonly used by the public.He explained the statutory guidance will apply in certain types of new buildings or in existing buildings where there is a material change of use.The new guidance has been published on Wednesday and will officially come into effect on June .It covers a range of building types and settings, including shopping centres, leisure and sport buildings and hospitals and primary care centres.Ms Hollywood said: “The reality of this guidance means that thousands of people will be able to go to the cinema without the worry of how they are going to go to the toilet.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Having Changing Places toilets in more buildings will reduce isolation, improve mental health and esteem in disabled people who need these facilities. Disabled people will no longer need to choose between fun and going to the toilet - one of our most basic needs as a society.”The Crossgar woman added: “It will also mean for many disabled people that they will no longer be forced into surgical options to resolve their toileting needs. The impact of the new guidance will have far reaching positive impacts on our economy and I’m delighted it’s coming into effect.”Absolutely landmark moment for Northern Ireland as #ChangingPlaces toilets set to become mandatory in certain public buildings! Thanks to @dptfinance  @conormurphysf for making this happen. A long term historical change for our People.Freedom, here I come.#IncLOOsion https:t.co moiRAmXbiX— Michaela HollywoodMarch , According to the Department of Finance, the new requirement for Changing Places toilets will be in addition to the current requirements for standard accessible toilets and will benefit around , people here.They also confirmed plans to carry out research in the next mandate on further extending the provision of Changing Places toilets.This would include requiring inclusive toilets in specied buildings where building work is to be carried out to extend or alter an existing building.Other campaigners also welcomed the move, including mother Christine McClements.After years of campaigning I am absolutely thrilled with today#s announcement for mandatory provision of changing places toilets,” she said.“This change to our Building Regulations will not only bring increased safe, dignied and convenient toileting opportunities for disabled people and many older people too, but it will also bring new opportunities for inclusion and participation right across society.“My disabled daughter Lilia spent many years having to be changed on an unhygienic public toilet floor. I hope that a new generation of disabled children will now never have to face that indignity.“Today is a very good and signicant day for the advancement of the equality and rights of disabled people here.Related topicsConor MurphyMore On Conor Murphy£m allocated to teachers’ pay, transport, heating of social housing and energy costs PremiumEconomy is being distorted by Invest NI focusing on Belfast, claims MLAMurphy pays fiver for personal use of Stormont carSinn Fein favours a single .% corporation tax for smaller firms on both sides of border Premium, children waiting for help from NI mental health servicesMost ReadFloundering council’s £,-a-day boss quits just days into role – putting fourth person in charge in three monthsDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ of child’s deathThe cheapest quotes for heating oil in your Northern Ireland postcode area as prices expected to remain high for two yearsNorthern Ireland braced for strong winds as Met Eireann issue gale warning for islandTwo children taken to hospital following three-car collision in west BelfastTop VideosPlayVideo: Ukrainian soldiers use Northern Ireland built NLAW on invading Russian tanksPlayVideo: CCTV shows the moment thieves rob Moneymore store of k of stockPlayVideo: Two children hospitalised as car overturns in west BelfastLatest Northern IrelandBrexit not as calamitous for Ireland as feared, politicians toldUK Government should ‘see what more we can do’ in Ukraine, claims DUP leader DonaldsonGlentoran -
